channel.title: Homes on Clinical Machine Learning Group
channel.description: Recent content in Homes on Clinical Machine Learning Group

item.description: The Clinical Machine Learning Group at MIT works at the intersection of statistical theory and clinical practice. Led by Professor David Sontag, our group includes graduate students, clinicians, undergraduates, and post-docs. ðŸš€

Biography David Sontag joined the MIT faculty in 2017 as Assistant Professor in the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science (EECS), Hermann L.F. von Helmholtz Career Development Professor in the Institute for Medical Engineering and Science (IMES), and principal investigator in the Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL). Professor Sontag’s research interests are in machine learning and artificial intelligence. As part of IMES, he leads a research group that aims to transform healthcare through the use of machine learning.

item.title: Research
item.description: Our lab is broadly interested in advancing machine learning and artificial intelligence, and using these to transform health care. We currently have three main focus areas: Theoretical machine learning Precision medicine Intelligent electronic health records Theoretical Machine Learning We research unsupervised learning, causal inference from observational data, deep learning, time-series modeling, approximate probabilistic inference, structured prediction, and semi-supervised learning algorithms for natural language processing. R. Krishnan, U. Shalit, D.

item.title: Software
item.description: Machine learning Python (Theano) code for learning Deep Markov Models (AAAI ‘17) Torch code for learning character-aware neural language models (AAAI ‘16) Python code for learning topic models (ICML ‘13). See also Mallet-compatible Java implementation Bayesian network structure learning (UAI ‘13). C++ code for MAP inference in graphical models (UAI ‘12). Readme file Health care Anchor Explorer Machine learning algorithm and user interface for learning to predict clinical state variables without having to label data (AMIA 2014, JAMIA 2016)

item.title: Teaching
item.description: Massachusetts Institute of Technology Machine Learning for Healthcare, Spring 2017 6.S897, HST.S53 Course description: Explores machine learning methods for clinical and healthcare applications. Covers concepts of algorithmic fairness, interpretability, and causality. Discusses application of time-series analysis, graphical models, deep learning and transfer learning methods to solving problems in healthcare. Considers how newly emerging machine learning techniques will shape healthcare policy and personalized medicine. New York University Fall 2016: Inference and Representation (DS-GA-1005 and CSCI-GA.
